explanation: Almost all advice listed in the original and widely spread Facebook messages was false. Facebook did not label these messages as misinformation in English or Dutch.

label: false
title: Drinking “water a lot and gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates” the coronavirus.
explanation: These claims have not been proven scientifically.

label: mostly false
title: “President Trump, COVID-19 coronavirus
explanation: As of 3/17/20, numbers that suggest H1N1 was worse than COVID-19 are misleading. It’s too early to calculate how deadly the coronavirus will be, but there are signs it’s much worse.

label: false
title: Evo Morales (ex-mandatary of Bolivia) has COVID-19.
explanation: Morales continue his normal activities. On 3/12/20, he posted on his Twitter account. Followers of the political party Movement to Socialism (MAS) did not refer to the health condition of the ex mandatary.

label: false
title: A Twitter post claimed Cristiano Ronaldo is transforming his string of hotels to hospitals to aid in the fight against COVID-19.
explanation: A spokesperson from the hotel denied the claim and there is no such statement present on any of the footballer’s media accounts.

label: false
title: Juventus player Paulo Dybala denies contracting coronavirus.
explanation: Paulo Dybala, on his Twitter account, denied on 3/13/20 that he had contracted the virus.

label: misleading
title: An infographic has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts which claim it shows a nine-day timeline of the symptoms of the novel coronavirus.
explanation: This infographic is misleading; it was not distributed by an official health authority and health experts say COVID-19 symptoms vary in duration and severity.

label: misleading
title: Sex helps prevent coronavirus.
explanation: There is no proof that sex can help fight the new coronavirus.

label: pants on fire!
title: Says The New York Times exposed the “real reason behind coronavirus hype
explanation: There's no evidence the coronavirus was manufactured. The New York Times story was an analysis of how current events may influence the election.

label: pants on fire!
title: In South Florida “all children and adults must remain in their homes” due to coronavirus.
explanation: Announcements from several major local governments in south Florida had no complete lockdown announcements. Governor Ron DeSantis closed bars and nightclubs statewide.

label: false
title: A vaccine for the 2019 novel coronavirus has been found and there will be no more deaths due to the coronavirus.
explanation: As of 3/20/20, there is no vaccine or cure for the disease caused by the 2019 novel coronavirus and there have been 217,510 cases and 9,020 deaths, across 157 countries.

label: false
title: Staff of Gold Coast Hospital in Australia has gifted a volleyball to Tom Hanks in quarantine.
explanation: The image has been morphed to claim that Tom Hanks was gifted a volleyball.

label: false
title: Eleven coronavirus patients visited malls and hotels in Metro Manila that are part of a “confidential list.”
explanation: The DOH has dismissed the claim as fake. The malls and hotels in question have not posted any advisories regarding possible infection.

label: mostly false
title: Aajtak news channel claims that consuming the herbal plant Tulsi will cure coronavirus.
explanation: The WHO has not confirmed the claim. Aajtak channel has not run this information. The viral photo with channel logo is fake.

label: false
title: A post says that if you hold your breath you can tell if you are infected with Covid-19 or not.
explanation: A pulmonologist and member of the National Public Health Commission assured that this exercise doesn’t have any clinical applicability and it’s not safe. You can do the exercise, pass it and be infected with COVID-19.

label: misleading
title: After contracting coronavirus, did Tom Hanks get Wilson’s ball In quarantine?
explanation: The original image is from a video published in February 2015.

label: false
title: An article about “An Italian doctor working in China gives advice on avoiding infection.”
explanation: The article is filled with outdated and false advice on how to cure the virus. None have been officially confirmed by the WHO or any other relevant institution.

label: false
title: Drinking cold water, hot drinks or alcohol protects against coronavirus.
explanation: These claims hold no medical value.

label: false
title: Airports and train stations in Lithuania are being closed down.
explanation: The article used a statement by the government claiming that schools are being closed. Authors of the misleading article added information about airports and train stations in a headline but used the government's statement as main text.

label: false
title: COVID-19 is cured with hot water and baking soda.
explanation: Mortality statistics indicate that seasonal flu is at least 60 times less deadly than COVID-19 (based on current data). Hot water and soda have no proven effects to help combat the novel coronavirus.

label: false
title: Claim that disease outbreaks and pandemics correspond with election years.
explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found no correlation between election years and virus outbreaks. The outbreaks of SARS, Bird Flu and COVID-19 do not line up with the dates claimed in the post. In the case of Zika virus, the disease has had multiple outbreaks since 2014 in parts of Oceania and in Brazil. Bird Flu, MERS and Ebola have not been reported in Australia and have not been a significant feature of local political discussion or debate. Considering overseas elections, such as U.S. presidential elections, there is also no consistent pattern of outbreaks occurring in election years.

label: false
title: Audio from WhatsApp that says there are a doctor and two nurses hospitalized on the ICU in Terrassa (Barcelona)
explanation: The hospitals in Terrassa deny this claim.

label: false
title: Picture shows the Mecca totally empty.
explanation: The picture is designed by an artist.

label: false
title: Photo purportedly showing Tom Hanks holding a volleyball, claiming the hospital staff in Australia gave it to him as a tribute and to cheer him up while in quarantine.
explanation: The image has been doctored using a 2015 photograph of Hanks and a stock photo of a hospital ward; the doctored photo emerged on a satirical website.

label: false
title: Saddam Hussein explains what coronavirus is about.
explanation: The sound has been edited. The video from 2003 shows Saddam Hussein talking about the US/Iraq war.

label: misleading
title: Get the disease now to gain immunity. Infograph mimicking official information.
explanation: "If you are infected with coronavirus, take a stroll in the sauna and breathe deeply for 20 minutes and kill the infection." This is how recommendation sounds on the web. But the council does not have teams in reality, say experts, who at the same time state that instead, it is very easy to risk infecting others.
claim_originated_by: Meme page for high school students

label: misleading
title: Denmark has more coronavirus cases per capita than China.
explanation: One should be careful about letting the number of infections express how coronavirus is spreading in Denmark. And one should also be careful to compare the figures across countries as they are made up in vastly different ways

label: false
title: Elderly people are left to die in an Italian hospital near Milan.
explanation: Information was based on an audio message circulating via WhatsApp. The message was posted by Il Giornale, which later retracted it. Niguarda hospital released a statement claiming the information was false.

label: false
title: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said “the WHO recommends hot drinks because heat kills the virus”
explanation: The organization did not issue any recommendation on the consumption of beverages for the prevention of coronavirus. Experts deny this advice and say that it could be harmful.
claim_originated_by: Alberto Fernández (Argentine President) on Radio Mitre

label: false
title: In Colombia, “First Child registered as Yair coronavirus Mosquera.”
explanation: The screenshot of the alleged note from Caracol has been broadcast on social networks.

label: false
title: Mexicans can call the Mexican government to get a COVID-19 test at home.
explanation: The UIES line was enabled only for suspicious cases and not for the general population.

label: misleading
title: Photos show empty shelves at supermarkets.
explanation: The photos have circulated online since 2015.

label: false
title: Warm drinks kill the coronavirus, the virus dies when the ambient temperature is higher than 26ºC, gargling warm water helps treating the disease and the virus stays on your hands for 10 minutes.
explanation: None of these claims have scientific support.

label: misleading
title: A video purports to show body bags for virus victims in Italy.
explanation: The video previously circulated in media reports about people who died after contracting COVID-19 in Iran; a man recording the video can be heard stating that he is inside a mortuary in the Iranian city of Qom.

label: false
title: 3,500 Italians potentially infected with the novel coronavirus arrived in Brazil in a cruise ship
explanation: The photo shared with misinformation is from the Costa Fascinosa cruise, and the company responsible for the vessel reported that all of its passengers in Brazil are from South America. The ship left Italy on 11/17/19, passed through France and Spain and has been on the Brazilian coast since 12/2/19, two months before Italy confirmed its first coronavirus case.

label: false
title: The Brazilian government released additional money for beneficiaries of Bolsa Família, a national conditional cash transfer programme.
explanation: The Ministry of Citizenship, responsible for the program, denied on its social networks that there will be such a release and stated that it only announced the inclusion of 1.2 million families in Bolsa Família. Messages circulating on WhatsApp with this misinformation link to fake websites.

label: false
title: Hot lemon juice prevents coronavirus.
explanation: The claim is false. The publication allegedly written by "Laila Ahmadi of China, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Zanjan University" is false and that university is not located in China.

label: false
title: News channels suggest drinking tulsi and noni juice will help prevent the novel coronavirus.
explanation: A morphed screenshot of the news channel was used to support the false claim.

label: no evidence
title: Argentine President Alberto Fernández said that coronavirus dies at 26 degrees Celsius.
explanation: The WHO maintains that the virus can be transmitted in all climates and "the virus is too new for us to know how a warmer climate could affect transmissibility." According to the CDC, it is not yet known whether climate and temperature affect the spread of COVID-19.
claim_originated_by: Alberto Fernández (Argentine President) on Radio Mitre

label: false
title: Infographic claiming that the coronavirus pandemic fits a pattern of viral outbreaks that occur every 100 years.
explanation: The infographic contains inaccurate information about historical viral outbreaks and ignores other epidemics that do not fit the assumed pattern; health experts told AFP that while certain viruses are seasonal in nature, there is no basis for the claim that viral outbreaks occur once every century.

label: false
title: KFC San Marino Shopping (Guayaquil, Ecuador) employee with COVID-19.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Jair Bolsonaro tested positive for COVID-19.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Iranians have published a report saying that coronavirus is a biological warfare.
explanation: There was no such report and claims about coronavirus being biological warfare have been debunked.

label: false
title: Most countries affected by COVID-19 are along the same 40-degree north latitude.
explanation: The 40-degree north latitude passes through some of the countries most affected by COVID-19 but does not pass through half of the locations in the post. It does not touch Wuhan (Hubei Province – where around 60% of all the positive cases are reported), which is at around 30-degree north latitude.

label: false
title: A former and controversial CIA officer said coronavirus was made in a lab.
explanation: The quote was pulled out of context and was speculation, not fact.

label: false
title: Australian hospital staff rolled in a Wilson volleyball to keep Tom Hanks company in quarantine.
explanation: This claim is from a satirical website. The photo is old and unrelated to Tom Hanks' illness.

label: false
title: Garlic heals the new coronavirus.
explanation: The WHO said there is no evidence to prove this claim.

label: false
title: OMS staff member is spreading coronavirus on purpose.
explanation: The man is an astrophysicist, and he is touching the woman because she is his girlfriend, and she is sick.

label: false
title: Drinking water in which garlic was boiled will cure you from COVID-19.
explanation: There is no evidence to support this claim.

label: false
title: Jair Bolsonaro has the new coronavirus.
explanation: Health authorities have not confirmed the case and they are the ones who can test.

label: false
title: The U.S. presidential election is canceled due to coronavirus.
explanation: The federal government has made no such announcement about canceling the U.S. presidential election.

label: false
title: A worker at the Prince hotel in Mehdipatnam (Hyderbad, India) has tested positive for coronavirus.
explanation: The claim is fake. In Telangana state, as of 3/12/20, only one confirmed case of coronavirus is reported and the person who tested positive is a software engineer.

label: explanatory
title: Viral audio from WhatsApp in which a doctor from the hospital Fundación Jiménez Díaz in Madrid claims that there are two young patients in very bad condition because of coronavirus and there are no more respirators in intensive care units.
explanation: In an internal document, the head of intensive care unit explains that the young patients have no pathologies related to coronavirus and there are respiratories for all patients.

label: false
title: UNICEF’s advice on preventing COVID-19
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Consuming onion and salt followed by a glass of water can cure coronavirus.
explanation: There is no scientific evidence to prove that onion, salt and water can be used to cure COVID-19. There is no cure for coronavirus.

label: false
title: Policemen in China chase COVID-19 in a subway station.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Consuming salt and onion can cure the novel coronavirus.
explanation: Sri Lankan health department officials have officially dismissed the claim.

label: false
title: Indian President Ramnath Kovind pouring gaumutra (cow urine) on globe to prevent coronavirus.
explanation: The 2017 image is false.

label: false
title: Zamora has canceled Holy week due to the coronavirus.
explanation: It's a false article created on 12minutos, a site for satirical articles.

label: false
title: Podemos spokesman Pablo Echenique is not in intensive care after getting infected with COVID-19.
explanation: The tweet imitated El Mundo's official account.

label: misleading
title: A video of Chinese people fighting for Muslim scriptures to not get infected by coronavirus.
explanation: The video has been circulating since 2014, before the coronavirus was first reported in late December 2019. It shows Christians in China opening their Bibles for the first time

label: false
title: Chinese people prayed with Muslims due to fear of COVID-19.
explanation: The video was shared in June 2019, before the outbreak.

label: false
title: Audio from WhatsApp that says there are a doctor and two nurses hospitalized on the ICU in Terrassa (Barcelona)
explanation: The hospitals in Terrassa deny this situation.

label: false
title: China has announced the success of Egyptian serum form Dr. Hala, Health Minister of Egypt, against coronavirus
explanation: Egyptian Health Ministry denied it.

label: misleading
title: Turmeric and lemon can cure the coronavirus.
explanation: Medical practitioners and the WHO say this claim is false.

label: partially false
title: The smell of tea tree oil can kill coronavirus in nostrils, according to a study of an Austrian university.
explanation: It works in a lab, but there is no evidence to prove that smelling oil for 15 minutes can kill the coronavirus.

label: false
title: You can check for coronavirus by holding your breath for 10 seconds.
explanation: There is no evidence to support the claim.

label: false
title: Education Ministry announces all students are passing the actual course without making exams because of coronavirus.
explanation: The education ministry issued another document that was manipulated.

label: false
title: Councilor Pen White-Chung said coronavirus is from the USA based on a Chinese academic study.
explanation: The information is based on an unfounded claim shared by China officials.

label: false
title: Drinking water every 15 minutes will protect you from getting coronavirus.
explanation: There is no medical evidence to support this.

label: false
title: President Donald Trump admitted the flu cases in the USA are actually infected with the coronavirus.
explanation: The video is a clip of Trump's speech, but the subtitle and caption are false.

label: false
title: Tuit reports that Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro has tested positive for the coronavirus.
explanation: This is a fake Twitter account pretending to be Folha de Sao Paulo.

label: false
title: Catalonia, Valencia and Aragon cancel classes in schools, colleges and universities because of coronavirus outbreak.
explanation: The article was not published by El País.

label: half true
title: Of the Trump administration’s European travel restrictions that exempt the U.K.
explanation: It isn't that easy to get around the restrictions by taking a train linking England and France.

label: false
title: Says Nancy Pelosi was “caught trying to include abortion funding in bill to combat coronavirus.”
explanation: The U.S. House passed a measure that provides federal funds to people affected by the coronavirus. The bill covers reimbursement laboratory costs for COVID-19 testing. Some raised concerns that language was needed to ensure abortion services weren't eligible to receive funds. The language was amended by Democrats to limit reimbursements to COVID-19 expenses.

label: false
title: “The CDC can detain anyone with a fever indefinitely. Vaccination (is) a way people could get out of detention.”
explanation: In the United States, people can't be quarantined for just a fever; they have to be shown to have been exposed to one of a specific set of diseases. Most quarantines are voluntary, not by force of the government. Vaccination is not a ticket out of quarantine. Most quarantine decisions are up to states and localities, rather than the CDC.

label: false
title: COVID-19 came to the United States in 2019.
explanation: The first confirmed COVID-19 case in the United States was reported on 1/20/20. The patient was a man who had recently returned to Washington state from Wuhan, China.

label: mostly false
title: Saint Luke’s Hospital of the USA says consuming alcohol can reduce the risk of COVID-19.
explanation: Saint Luke's Hospital has not issued this advisory.

label: false
title: The new coronavirus dies when a temperature around is 26-27 degrees Celsius.
explanation: The virus doesn't die when the temperature is around 27-28 degrees Celsius.

label: false
title: Vitamin C protects against the spread of the coronavirus. Lemon in hot water fights cancer. COVID-19 arises from the fusion of genetic material of a snake and a bat.
explanation: These claims are not proven.

label: false
title: A fake quote of Vice President Leni Robredo suggesting to “inhale cough back” to prevent the spread of the 2019 novel coronavirus.
explanation: The vice president did not say what was attributed to her in the graphic. News5 said the graphic was edited using their template.

label: false
title: If you donate blood, “they HAVE to test you” for coronavirus.
explanation: Blood donors don’t get a coronavirus test if they donate blood.

label: mostly false
title: Donald Trump claims Joe Biden “was in charge of the H1N1 Swine Flu epidemic which killed thousands of people. The response was one of the worst on record. Our response is one of the best, with fast action of border closings and a 78% approval rating, the highest on record. His was lowest!”
explanation: Joe Biden was not in charge of the Obama administration’s H1N1 response. Trump overstated public confidence in his administration’s response to the coronavirus and downplayed confidence in the Obama administration’s response to H1N1.

label: false
title: A video has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows a shaman curing a novel coronavirus patient in Malaysia.
explanation: The claim is false. The video has circulated in posts about a hospital in Indonesia since at least October 2018, more than one year before COVID-19 was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

label: false
title: Private health insurance for public workers does not cover expenses related to coronavirus.
explanation: The statement published by Independent Union of the Tax Agency of Spain on 3/12/20 is real, and the public institution (MUFACE) affirm that all its insured (public workers) have 100% coverage in expenses related to COVID-19.

label: mostly true
title: “During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden made reckless comments unsupported by science & the experts. The Obama Admin had to clean up his mess & apologize for his ineptitude.”
explanation: During the 2009 swine flu outbreak, Biden said he would advise his family against traveling in confined places and said when one person sneezes “it goes all the way through an aircraft.” Scientists say that’s not how germs spread. Biden’s comments were met with backlash and his spokesperson issued a clarification.

label: false
title: Says Tom Hanks has a volleyball to keep him company while he’s quarantined.
explanation: The image of Tom Hanks holding a Wilson volleyball during his COVID-19 quarantine is from a satirical Australian website.

label: false
title: In 2007, “The Simpsons” predicted Tom Hanks would contract coronavirus in 2007.
explanation: In the closing credits of “The Simpson Movie,” Hanks says

label: false
title: A doctor from North Macedonia states that the new coronavirus outbreak  is a conspiracy against humanity or a conspiracy of the pharmaceutical industry for profit, and that the new coronavirus is not dangerous.
explanation: The text contradicts recognized authorities and institutions, such as the WHO, which has  declared a pandemic of the new coronavirus and confirmed its seriousness.

label: misleading
title: Live stream about the infected foreigners coming to Ukraine from Italy, which went viral.
explanation: The passengers on that plane were not infected and some of the information by the speaker was false.

label: false
title: Policemen in China chase COVID-19 in a subway station.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: UNICEF’s advice on preventing COVID-19
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

location: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Greece
label: false
title: The virus can be overcome by drinking hot water every 15 minutes, avoiding cold drinks and ice cream, going out in the sun to kill the virus, and with the “self-diagnostic guideline” — if you hold your breath for 10 seconds and then you do not cough, you do not choke, you do not feel any tension in the lungs, you have no cystic fibrosis in the lungs and the situation is reversible.
explanation: These claims are false. The virus enters the oral cavity and the nose, so drinking hot water will not carry the virus to the stomach. Viruses are destroyed at higher temperatures than those normally tolerated by humans, and even sun exposure and body heat have no effect.

label: false
title: Spain ex-King Juan Carlos I has the coronavirus.
explanation: The claim was tweeted from a fake account pretending to be Spanish newspaper El País.

label: false
title: The new coronavirus dies at a temperature of about 26-27 degrees Celsius.
explanation: The virus doesn't die when the temperature is around 27-28 degrees Celsius.

label: false
title: Cuba has developed a vaccine against coronavirus.
explanation: Cuba is working on a vaccine option, but it is not ready for distribution; Facebook posts mention Interferon Alfa 2B, a medicine used against hepatitis.

label: false
title: A YouTube video claims to show mass animal killings linked to coronavirus outbreak.
explanation: The pig footage dates back to 2018 and the poultry footage did not depict contaminated animals.

label: false
title: Jair Bolsonaro tested positive for COVID-19.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: KFC San Marino Shopping (Guayaquil, Ecuador) employee with COVID-19.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Prime Minister Ana Brnabic claimed that the number of respirators is a state secret in all countries.
explanation: Information about number of respirators is available in many countries.

label: false
title: Drinking tea and hot water kills the virus; lemon slices in warm water may save your life; it’s recommended to keep your money in a sealed plastic bag; a conspiracy theory suggests China is benefiting from the pandemic; vinegar is good for cleaning your hands.
explanation: Coronavirus has already spread to countries with hot weather; water with lemons does not help prevention; the WHO recommends washing your hands after touching your money; Asian markets have been operating in low marks because of the pandemic; the WHO recommends using alcohol gel and soap to clean your hands.

label: misleading
title: Coronavirus first infection In Jeddah..
explanation: The first infection with COVID-19 in Jeddah, a woman from an Asian country showing symptoms of suspected coronavirus, and falling on a street. The Emirate of Makkah Province denied, on its Twitter account, what was circulated about the infection of a Chinese woman with the virus.

label: misleading
title: The novel coronavirus after 2,600 times magnified.
explanation: The image is enlarged to show mites, not coronavirus.

label: false
title: Holding your breath for 10 seconds can determine if you have COVID-19; drink water every 15 minutes.
explanation: The article lists myths that contradict WHO recommendations.

label: false
title: Muslim People in China seeking refuge in Islam by reading Quran to save themselves from COVID-19.
explanation: The video has existed since 2013, long before the outbreak of COVID-19.

label: false
title: AIIMS (Indian medical institute) team has said that Toddy has medicinal properties to cure coronavirus.
explanation: AIIMS team did not make the statement.

label: false
title: Photo of vegan food products left on otherwise bare supermarket shelf is related to COVID-19 outbreak and panic buying.
explanation: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be incorrectly linking the supermarket shelf image to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The image of a supermarket shelf full of vegan foods while the shelves on either side remain empty has nothing to do with the outbreak. The photo was taken in 2017 in the United States when Hurricane Harvey hit the southern state of Texas.

label: false
title: Vitamin C and lemon water prevent coronavirus.
explanation: There is no recommendation from the WHO or scientific evidence to support this. There is no vaccine or medication for COVID-19.

label: false
title: Iran’s head of judiciary
explanation: Weeks after the outbreak, holy shrines and mosques refused to close down.
claim_originated_by: Iran's head of judiciary, Ebrahim Raiesi

label: false
title: Imported second hand clothes from Europe, Asia or America could spread the novel coronavirus in Africa.
explanation: Experts told AFP the novel coronavirus does not survive long enough outside the human body, and could not survive on long journeys.

label: false
title: Hold your breath 10 seconds to check if you are infected with the novel coronavirus.
explanation: Only a test made by labs can detect the novel coronavirus, according to the WHO and some experts interviewed by AFP.

label: false
title: Actor Daniel Radcliffe tested positive for covid-19.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Japanese doctors claim drinking water every 15 minutes prevents COVID-19.
explanation: No Japanese advisory has been issued regarding frequent consumption of water. The WHO has clarified that drinking water will not prevent a coronavirus infection.

label: false
title: Quito is the second city with the highest probability of infection.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: misleading
title: No more deaths from COVID-19 as Israeli scientists have discovered a vaccine.
explanation: Various vaccines proposed by Israeli scientists and other researchers across the world are under development and are yet to be cleared for production and distribution. Israel’s MIGAL Research Institute is also in the process of producing a vaccine for COVID-19. According to the WHO, as of 3/11/20, there is no vaccine for COVID-19.

label: false
title: Anti-Malaria Drug Chloroquine Is A Cure For Coronavirus.
explanation: This claim is false. There is no scientific evidence to prove that Chloroquine can cure COVID-19.

label: misleading
title: Chart compares COVID-19 with other longstanding diseases.
explanation: The graphic is misleading and risks underplaying the danger of COVID-19, which is a new disease with a fast-rising mortality rate.

label: false
title: If you can hold your breath for 10 seconds then you don’t have fibrosis and therefore no infection. Picture of text in English describing the method.
explanation: The recommendation to hold your breath for 10 seconds is shared in several different social media posts. Supposedly, it can reveal if you have pneumonia, which is one of the symptoms if you have been infected with the coronavirus, COVID-19. But closing your mouth, holding your nose for ten seconds, and waiting for you to cough or not, you can't use for anything, experts say.

label: false
title: Gargling salt water and vinegar will kill the virus.
explanation: Pulmonologist debunked the memes, and CDC offers real advice about how to say safe.

label: misleading
title: Why it’s dangerous to make your own hand sanitizer at home.
explanation: DIY videos don't' tell you it's dangerous.

label: false
title: Racist scene against Chinese people in the metro in Belgium.
explanation: Vidéo is an excerpt of the Youtube channel "Would you react" with actors.

label: false
title: A case of new coronavirus was confirmed in the city of Ibagué, in Colombia.
explanation: Health authorities had not confirmed the case and they were the only ones to be able to do so because they are the ones who can test.

label: false
title: Coronavirus found in toilet paper.
explanation: This claim was created by a prank generator, and the CDC did not cite it as a way coronavirus spreads.

label: false
title: Retirement benefits reduced by 50% in April in Italy.
explanation: The public statement was fake. The national social welfare institution has never shared that document.

label: false
title: Racist scene against Chinese people in the metro in Belgium.
explanation: Vidéo is an excerpt of the Youtube channel "Would you react" with actors.

label: misleading
title: Malaga closes nurseries due to coronavirus.
explanation: The image a manipulated screenshot of an El Mundo article.

label: false
title: “Arsenic album-30 homeopathic medicine can prevent coronavirus. Information given by Ministry of AYUSH.”
explanation: According to the WHO, there is no evidence that any medicine can stop or cure the coronavirus. The WHO does not recommend any medication, including antibiotics, as a prevention or treatment of COVID-19. The AYUSH Minister Mr. Padnaik never claimed that arsenic album 30 can cure coronavirus.

label: false
title: A video claims to show coronavirus being extracted from a man’s upper lip.
explanation: A botfly larva is being extracted from the man's lip in the video.

label: false
title: Pedro Sánchez has a medical team of 14 people to take care of him since the coronavirus crisis.
explanation: The medical team has been in the presidential house since 1997, and has nothing to do with COVID-19.

label: false
title: Uganda did not deport 19 passengers from high-risk COVID-19 countries.
explanation: Ugandan authorities did not deport 19 passengers on a KLM flight from Amsterdam to Entebbe. The passengers did not show severe flu-like symptoms.

label: false
title: Seven ambulance workers are infected with coronavirus in Catalonia.
explanation: Health ministry of Catalonia confirmed there are no ambulance workers infected.

label: false
title: Neuroscientist Rodolfo Llinás says that if you can last 10 seconds without coughing and without discomfort it means that there is no fibrosis in the lungs and therefore no coronavirus infection.
explanation: Rodolfo Llinás claims he did not say that and there is no evidence the recommendations are effective.

label: false
title: Demonstrations against Chinese people in Italy.
explanation: Anti-fascist demonstration on February 22 in Roma.

label: false
title: UNICEF published health advice on COVID-19.
explanation: UNICEF did not publish the text. The medical advice in the text is not scientifically-based.

label: false
title: The health insurance industry has “agreed to waive all co-payments for coronavirus treatments.”
explanation: Health insurance companies said they will waive costs for coronavirus tests, not treatment. A shortage in diagnostic supplies means that testing is limited.

label: false
title: Indian yoga guru Baba Ramdev has been infected with coronavirus.
explanation: A photo of Ramdev is from 2011 and shared with a false caption. It was taken in Dehradun after the yoga guru broke his nine-day fast. He had been on a hunger strike demanding a tougher law against corruption and seeking the return of black money stashed abroad.

label: false
title: The virus dies with high temperatures, teas fight COVID-19, holding your breath for 10 seconds proves you are not infected, drinking a lot of water stops the coronavirus, any mask can avoid contagion, coronavirus does die when “exposed to the sun.”
explanation: These claims are false, according to the WHO and medical experts.

label: false
title: Is this COVID-19 Virus Prevention Information Really Originating from UNICEF?
explanation: UNICEF has denied this post and information circulating in a number of countries, including Indonesia.

label: false
title: Water company
explanation: The water company did not release such a statement and did not add to the water.

label: false
title: Cow urine and feces can treat COVID-19.
explanation: No health organization has confirmed drugs or vaccines to prevent and treat COVID-19.

label: false
title: The map shows the first COVID-19 case diagnosed in Kayseri, Turkey.
explanation: The Johns Hopkins map shows the geographical centers of the countries, not the places in which case are diagnosed. Metadata shows the details.

label: false
title: Coronavirus dies at a temperature above 26-27 degrees Celsius as per UNICEF.
explanation: The claim was not issued by UNICEF.

label: false
title: American CDC admitted that coronavirus originated in the U.S. Many COVID-19 patients were misdiagnosed as coronavirus.
explanation: The claim that coronavirus came from the United States is false.

label: explanatory
title: Are pools open in Guatemala? Can coronavirus be transmitted in a pool?
explanation: Pools were closed by the Swimming Federation of Guatemala to avoid infections.

label: false
title: “NYC man drops dead in middle of street — suspected coronavirus!”
explanation: New York City Police say a man was taken to the hospital after falling and hitting his head. He was in stable condition and it was unrelated to coronavirus.

label: false
title: “MSNBC actually said on air ‘I hope enough people die from coronavirus that it harms Trump’s re-election.’”
explanation: MSNBC panelists compared former President George W. Bush’s response to Hurricane Katrina to President Donald Trump’s response to the coronavirus outbreak, and speculated it could hurt his popularity.

label: false
title: Madrid is going to close its borders due to the coronavirus.
explanation: The claim is denied by the Spanish police on Twitter.

label: false
title: Indonesia Only Prohibits Migrants from Iran, Italy, and South Korea and Allows the Entry of Chinese Citizens
explanation: Restrictions on the entry of migrants from China have been done earlier by the government, on 2/5/20. In addition to stopping flights to and from China, the government has temporarily suspended the issuance of Visas and Arrival Visas for Chinese citizens.

label: misleading
title: “The Eyes of Darkness” predicted the coronavirus outbreak.
explanation: "The Eyes of Darkness," published in 1981, predicts the emergence of COVID-19. In the book's new edition, the author talks about a biological weapon, a virus called "Wuhan 400", originating from the same city in China. He did not mention COVID-19 or its main symptoms such as shortness of breath and high temperature.

label: false
title: A viral screenshot of a story allegedly published by the BBC claiming Ghana has recorded its first confirmed coronavirus case.
explanation: The claim was denied by the BBC correspondent in Ghana and the Ghana Health Service. The misinformers modified the HTML codes from the BBC website to create the false headline and story.

label: false
title: Welfare Ministry for the Region Lombardy has said that “China lied to us” and “all of the data provided by the Chinese government are fake.”
explanation: The Welfare Ministry never made this statement. It simply stated that COVID-19 is spreading faster than what forecasts suggested.

label: false
title: Audio from WhatsApp in which the head of Cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital states that we are in a moment of uncontrolled coronavirus infection.
explanation: The public health authorities of the Community of Madrid have said the audio belonging to the head of cardiology at the Gregorio Marañón Hospital is false.

label: false
title: About 1,000 people wait to enter the Military Medical Academy (VMA) in Belgrade for examinations.
explanation: People came for routine check-ups and only their temperature was measured. Many people were only accompanying those who went for a check-up and were not allowed to enter thus causing queues outside.

label: mostly false
title: China is supplying the Quran to people to read after the coronavirus outbreak.
explanation: This seven-year-old video has no relation to coronavirus.

label: false
title: Demonstrations against Chinese people in Italy.
explanation: An anti-fascist demonstration took place on 2/22/20 in Roma.

label: false
title: Neuroscientist Rodolfo Llinás says that if you can last 10 seconds without coughing and without discomfort it means that there is no fibrosis in the lungs and therefore no coronavirus infection.
explanation: Rodolfo Llinás claims he did not say that and there is no evidence the recommendations are effective.

label: false
title: Panic scene in Germany with people rushing into a supermarket.
explanation: The video was made during the sales.

label: false
title: The coronavirus was created in the laboratory and is a biological weapon.
explanation: The claims are based on the opinions of two men who are not virologists, but rather conspirationists.

label: false
title: Actor Daniel Radcliffe tested positive for COVID-19.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Racist scene against Chinese people in the metro in Belgium.
explanation: Video is an excerpt from the Youtube channel "Would you React" with actors.

label: false
title: President Vucic claims that no one said coronavirus is the “funniest” virus.
explanation: The video of renewed doctor claiming that coronavirus is the "funniest" virus exists and is available online.

label: misleading
title: A picture of the Chinese President in Wuhan without a mask.
explanation: The image is old and has been posted on the official Chinese news agency Xinhua website since October 2018.

label: false
title: A doctor says coronavirus doesn’t kill or cause the common cold.
explanation: The doctor's claims contradict official information from the WHO.

label: false
title: Video shows a WHO official inappropriately touching a female attendee during a briefing session in China about the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. Same video was also used with another claim that the man is an Australian politician.
explanation: Video was taken out of context. The man in the video is a 2006 Nobel Prize laureate in physics, Professor George Smoot, not someone from WHO or a politician. The clip shows Smoot attending a business conference in Julu County in Hebei Province in China in June 2018 with his significant other who had a sore back at the time.

label: false
title: 200 new cases of COVID-19 registered in Lithuania. People are “cleansed with bleach” at the Vilnius international airport and taken to a small tent-town nearby.
explanation: One COVID-19 case is confirmed in Lithuania as of 3/10/20. Officials claim there was no such "explosion" in cases.

label: no evidence
title: Some blood groups are protected from the COVID-19.
explanation: A preliminary Chinese study says so. This is an interesting lead, but we are still far from sure this is a fact.

label: false
title: Recommendations of Dr. “González Ayala” are circulating on WhatsApp.
explanation: Dr. Silvia González Ayala denied that she was the author of the recommendations and said that she will file a criminal complaint.The text has several false claims.

label: false
title: This video shows a coronavirus patient in Mexico persecuted by the press.
explanation: The video was recorded on 2/18/20 at the Instituto Nacional Cardiopulmonar, Tórax de Honduras.

label: false
title: Tips against coronavirus like holding your breath and drinking water.
explanation: These tips don't prevent infection with coronavirus.

label: misleading
title: Argentinian Health Minister said there is no possibility the coronavirus exists in Argentina.
explanation: In January 2020, González García suggested that at that time "there is no possibility that there is coronavirus in Argentina", and that, if there was a case in the country, it would be imported, which did happen.

label: false
title: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon are effective ways of preventing COVID-19.
explanation: Vitamin C and warm water have no known effects on the novel coronavirus.

label: false
title: Drinking hot tea can prevent coronavirus infection.
explanation: Drinking hot tea has no effect on the novel coronavirus.

label: mainly false
title: If your nose is running you don’t have Covid-19. The virus dies at 27 degrees celsius, thererfore you should drink hot water or tea. The most common way to get infected is to touch surfaces. Every normal mask can filter the virus because it is very big.
explanation: The claims are false or unproven. A running nose can be a symptom of COVID-19. The virus doesn't die at 27 degrees, it can live with much higher temperatures. Drinking hot beverages doesn't cure or prevent the disease.

label: false
title: An audio is circulating on social media claiming it’s from the Colombian scientist Rodolfo Llinás offering some recommendations to know “if we have the infection” of the COVID-19 coronavirus.
explanation: Audio by Rodolfo Llinás with recommendations on the COVID-19 is false.

label: false
title: Senegal doctors have come up with a serum against the coronavirus.
explanation: The Senegal government has denied this claim; at present there is no treatment or vaccine against the novel coronavirus or COVID-19.

label: false
title: Quito is the second city with the highest probability of infection.

label: false

label: false
title: Thieves in Madrid are pretending to be doctors to steal from people’s houses.
explanation: National Police of Madrid explained that there is no complaint describing a similar case. "The note was made by the president of a neighborhood association who saw similar events on television but in a country abroad, not in Spain, so it is a hoax," they said.

label: false

explanation: Más País denied she was infected.

label: false

explanation: The herbal product image was manipulated.

label: half true

explanation: An epidemiologist at Harvard University projects 40%-70% of adults could catch coronavirus in the coming year.

label: mainly false

explanation: It was not a secret mission but the normal transfer of 23 asylum seekers from an initial reception site. This happens regularly.

Misbar found the news to be false and that the World Bank announced an initial financing package worth $12 billion to tackle COVID-19 in more than 60 countries in the world.

label: partially false

explanation: The National Expenditure Program (NEP), also known as "the President’s budget," initially proposed a lower budget for DOH for 2020 compared to 2019. This was eventually increased in the approved 2020 General Appropriations Act (GAA) or national budget after deliberations in Congress.

explanation: There is no medical and scientific evidence of this claim.

title: Anti-malaria drug Chloroquine is a definitive cure for COVID-19.

title: Madrid’s government has announced students will have to make-up classes during summer.
explanation: Madrid's government has not made this announcement; the shared photo is fake.

title: Availability of a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis.

explanation: This claim is baseless.

title: Gang in Madrid is pretending to be doctors to steal from people’s houses.

explanation: The French Health minister said that the risk of seeing the virus spreading in France was almost equal to zero, but it was at the very beginning of the outbreak in China and her statement was consistent with the data she had.

title: In an Aaj Tak news report, the Chinese prime minister said, “Reading Quran and offering namaz is the only cure for COVID-19.”
explanation: It is a clipped video of Aaj Tak’s fact-check. In the full version, Aaj Tak debunked the claim and concluded that no such statement was made by the Chinese PM.

explanation: It is a combination of old conspiracy theories.

title: Availability of a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis.

title: Prince of the United Arab Emirates was infected with the coronavirus in early March 2020
explanation: The Prince of the United Arab Emirates, Mohamed bin Zayed, is still active and not quarantined as of 3/9/20. The Twitter account that spread the false information has been closed.

explanation: The CDC is not making people pay the test by now.

label: false
title: “(Former U.S. President Barack Obama) set up anti-pandemic programs in 47 vulnerable countries as a way to protect against something like the coronavirus. Do you know that Trump closed 37 of them?”
explanation: News reports in early 2018 said the CDC was preparing to scale back its anti-pandemic programs in some countries because an early source of funding was running out and the agency didn't expect to receive new money from the Trump administration.The spending bills that lawmakers ultimately passed provided more money for those CDC programs than Trump’s budget requests.

label: misleading
title: People of the Muslim community have prohibited visiting Mecca Medina to avoid the outbreak of coronavirus, but people of Sanatan religion are playing Holi at the crematorium of Kashi Vishwanath as a pyre.
explanation: Mecca Medina of Saudi Arabia was not closed due to fear of coronavirus. There was a ban on the arrival of travelers from several countries. On 3/5/20 people were prevented from going inside because of sanitization.

title: Post says “being exposed to the sun for two hours” kills the 2019 coronavirus.
explanation: There is no evidence that sun exposure kills the 2019 coronavirus. UNICEF has debunked a post that makes this claim.

label: false

explanation: The person pictured is Sandra Oh, an actress from "Grey's Anatomy." There is no vaccine against coronavirus yet.

label: false

explanation: Researchers at the MIGAL Institute in Israel have announced a breakthrough in research, but they have not developed a vaccine.

label: false
title: The Department of Health (DOH) reports fake cigarettes that spread coronavirus have reached the Philippines.
explanation: The DOH did not issue any advisory on the transmission of the coronavirus through fake cigarettes or that they have reached the Philippines.

label: false
title: “An entire family” in Santolan, Pasig, is “confirmed to be infected” with the novel coronavirus, according to what looked like a breaking news graphic from GMA News.
explanation: Pasig City Mayor Vico Sotto called the graphic a “fake ‘GMA’ post.” The social media team of GMA News said they did not release the “JUST IN” graphic that circulated online.

label: false
title: Pier Luigi Bersani
explanation: In the interview, Bersani did not say the virus originated in Italy. He emphasized the virus is from China. The assumption is that the virus came to Italy prior to the time WHO declared the emergency.

label: false

explanation: The claim is from a fictional content outlet. Spanish government and mainstream media did not release such a statement.

label: mostly false

explanation: There is no evidence President Donald Trump came into direct contact with a coronavirus sufferer.

label: false
title: Turkish President Erdogan revealed a mask that kills coronavirus in a minute.
explanation: This information is not mentioned in the Turkish media.

label: mostly true
title: Says 80% of novel coronavirus cases are “mild.”
explanation: The website Information is Beautiful published a chart showing that 80.9% of novel coronavirus cases are "mild." But reports from the World Health Organization and the U.S. CDC found that mild cases account for 75-to-80% of all cases.

label: partially false
title: Chinese eating exotic animals is the cause of the 2019 novel coronavirus, as shown in photos shared on Facebook.
explanation: Some of the photos were not taken in China. As of 3/13/20, the coronavirus source is not confirmed.

explanation: Mutations of the virus exists, but it is uncorrect to claim that a "second version" would be more dangerous.

explanation: Madrid's government hasn't announced this and the shared photo is fake.

label: mostly false
title: Gargling with Betadine kills germs or reduces their numbers in the throat before they go down to the lungs, and a statement by Eleni Jamarely, professor of infectious diseases, claims that HIV is transmitted more easily from the new coronavirus through the spoon at communion.
explanation: This is incorrect because, according to the CDC, HIV infection in such a case is possible only if a person has an open wound in the mouth. Gargling with Betadine is dangerous because it is not said which Betadine product should be used. There is a special Betadine mouthwash product, whose efficiency on the novel coronavirus has not been proven yet and which can cause allergies for some people. Any other type of Betadine product can have counter-effects.
claim_originated_by: Professor of Infectious Diseases, Eleni Jamarelu and greek news portal

label: misleading
title: Availability of a kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis in Italy.
explanation: As of 3/9/20, there was no legal kit for coronavirus self-diagnosis. Only government authorities are authorized to do it.

explanation: Greta Thunberg were treated specially when she were allowed to visit the European Parliament, although all visits were canceled. But it is not at all correct that all visits were canceled.

label: false

explanation: A Facebook advertisement selling surgical masks links to a webpage for coronavirus self-diagnosis kits. As of 3/9/20 there was no kit developed legally for coronavirus self-diagnosis. Only government authorities are authorized to test for it.

Also, the number of pages in the largest editions did not exceed 280, so page number 365 does not exist as the fake post claims.

title: An Egyptian writer predicted the new coronavirus six years ago.

label: false
title: As of 3/7/20, Tanzania and Zambia had confirmed fist cases of the new coronavirus.

explanation: Saint Luke’s Hospital in Kansas City did not issue the letter, according to its staff.

label: false

explanation: The claim is false; the video has circulated online since at least 2013 with reports about people receiving copies of the Bible in China.

label: false

explanation: Our investigations show that almost everything this person who calls himself “professor” claims is fake and unfounded. His resume and bibliography are filled with fabricated items

explanation: The video is from Sakarya, not Istanbul, and the patient was isolated on inspection, not diagnosed. There is no case in Turkey as of 3/7/20.

explanation: The graphics and the tips are not from UNICEF

label: misleading
title: Did the coronavirus mutate and became more aggressive?
explanation: Chinese scientists discovered this coronavirus has two different types and that the second type could be more aggressive. But this is only a theory, never tested in lab and French scientists believe there no important mutation of the virus yet.

label: misleading
title: Coronavirus patients are being caught on highways in China.
explanation: The video is not about the coronavirus patients being caught, but of the training and mock drill given to the SWAT team in China.

label: false

explanation: The claim is false. There is no vaccine or medical treatment available for COVID-19. Cocaine is a stimulant and an addictive drug.

title: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Sincelejo in Colombia.
explanation: There is a possible case in Sincelejo which hasn't been confirmed as of 3/6/20.

label: misleading
title: People who died after being infected by the novel coronavirus can’t receive any mortuary care.
explanation: The HCSP (Haut conseil de la santé publique) told AFP not all mortuary care is forbidden for victims of the novel coronavirus. Embalming is forbidden but mortuary basic care can still be processed with additional precautions.

label: false
title: A case of coronavirus was confirmed in Cali in Colombia, and a video shows doctors treating patients in a bus station.
explanation: The video shows a drill organized by Cali's transportation authority, to prepare in case coronavirus arrives in the city.

label: misleading
title: An image has been shared in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter alongside a claim that it shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
explanation: The claim is misleading. The photos have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

label: false
title: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: A video says COVID-19 is caused by 5G.
explanation: The link between 5G and COVID-19 is not explained in the video and it does not hold any scientific value.

label: false
title: The mayor Of Buffalo told people to evacuate due to the coronavirus outbreak.
explanation: The mayor denied this claim when he responded to a Facebook post spreading the misinformation.

label: false
title: Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Muslims to understand why they are not contracting COVID-19.
explanation: The viral video is a combination of three clips of Xi Jinping visiting the northwest region of China in 2016.

label: false
title: Alcohol-based hand sanitizer can influence results in a breathalyzer test.
explanation: Spreading alcohol-based hand sanitizer does not affect the breathalyzer test.

label: false
title: Aaj Tak channel aired a program that said drinking alcohol or smoking weed can cure COVID-19.
explanation: Aaj Tak channel did not telecast such a program. The photos were taken from a fact-check episode debunking the claim and conclude that neither alcohol nor weed can cure COVID-19.

label: false
title: Work suspension in Ecuador due to coronavirus since Monday 09/03/2020.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: misleading
title: An image has been shared alongside a claim that shows China administering the “world’s first new coronavirus vaccine” after the global outbreak of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
explanation: The photos have circulated in reports about China testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine.

label: misleading
title: Vietnam was the first country to contain and develop a quick test for SARS and COVID-19.
explanation: The claim that Vietnam was the first country to contain SARS and develop a quick test kit is mostly legitimate. The claim that WHO says it takes four years to develop a test kit appears to be inaccurate.

label: partially false
title: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.
explanation: The post is partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of COVID-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the post are unrelated to COVID-19. The WHO says there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with COVID-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive."

label: false
title: Two local celebrities in Argentine are infected with coronavirus
explanation: The celebrities denied the claim.

label: misleading
title: A television news report about a US biotech company runs alongside a claim that the company successfully created a vaccine for the COVID-19 within “three hours.”
explanation: The U.S. biotech company said the vaccine requires human testing and will not be available until at least the end of 2020.

label: false
title: Medical report of Hospital General Universitario Santa Lucía de Cartagena (Murcia) from a person with possible coronavirus.
explanation: The medical report is old, and refers to another kind of coronavirus.

label: false
title: It is a designed virus ordered to laboratories by Christine Lagarde when she was in the IMF. She said that “old people live too long and this is a risk for the global economy. We must do something, urgently.”
explanation: There is no proof Lagarde said this.

label: false
title: Medical Center in El Cachorro (Sevilla) closed due to a possible coronavirus infected person.
explanation: The claim is false. Emergencies official channel of Sevilla denies it.

label: false
title: Emirates has suspended flights to Johannesburg after South Africa announced its first case of novel coronavirus.
explanation: The claim is false.

label: false
title: Turks are not going to be infected by COVID-19 due to their genes.
explanation: Distribution of the ACE2 protein among nations is not clear. Referred anthropologist was a Nazi and classified people by measuring body parts, not by genetic analysis.

label: false
title: Holding your breath for 10sec can determine if you have COVID-19 and you should drink water every 15 minutes.
explanation: There are no medical and scientific evidences

label: false
title: The consumption of pig causes COVID-19 entry into Indonesia.
explanation: COVID-19 spreads in Indonesia because there are Indonesian citizens who have contact with foreign citizens previously exposed to the coronavirus. Research shows that pigs carry only one virus that can be transmitted to humans, namely the H1N1 virus that causes swine flu.

label: false
title: A COVID-19 case has been diagnosed in Yedikule Hospital, Istanbul.
explanation: The lab report is outdated and shows other mild coronaviruses were found in the case

label: false
title: Girl infected with coronavirus found dead in her apartment in Delhi.
explanation: The incident in the post does not pertain to a coronavirus case in Delhi but is related to the death of a 22-year-old woman in Tamil Nadu’s Chettipedu.

label: mostly false
title: Bloggers say Nancy Pelosi delayed coronavirus funding so “Dems could campaign on it.”
explanation: President Donald Trump signed an $8.3 billion emergency spending bill to address the coronavirus on 3/6/20. There is no evidence House Speaker Nancy Pelosi delayed the bill for political ads.

label: explanatory
title: Increasing border controls will stop coronavirus from spreading.
explanation: Neither the WHO nor the CDC estimate that closing borders will stop the coronavirus

label: false
title: CDC sponsored Facebook post asking for help with “escaped” coronavirus patient.
explanation: The post was created by a fake CDC account.

label: pants on fire!
title: “Anybody that wants a test (for the coronavirus) can get a test.”
explanation: The CDC says health care providers decide whether someone gets tested for coronavirus.

label: false
title: If the coronavirus gets in your mouth, “drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through your esophagus and into the stomach. Once there, your stomach acid will kill all of the virus.”
explanation: There is no evidence that drinking water helps to prevent coronavirus infection. Health officials and media outlets have debunked the claim.

label: false
title: Coronavirus test costs US$3,000 in the U.S.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: mostly false
title: Pope Francis contacted coronavirus.
explanation: The Vatican confirms Pope Francis has not contracted coronavirus.

label: false
title: Medical book states that coronavirus is just a common cold.
explanation: COVID-19 is more dangerous than the common cold.

label: false
title: Chinese government is killing people who refuse to be evacuated.
explanation: Video is an edit from four videos taken out of context.

label: false
title: The test for coronavirus costs US$3,000 in the United States.
explanation: The only tests approved by FDA and CDC in the U.S. were provided for free. There may be secondary costs such as hospitalization or medical consultation.

label: false
title: Runny nose and coughing sputum are not symptoms of COVID-19.
explanation: In advisories issued by WHO, "runny nose" and "sputum production" are symptoms of COVID-19.

label: false
title: Monkeys are stealing food from a hospital in South Africa.
explanation: The video was taken before the COVID-19 crisis in a different part of the country.

label: false
title: WhatsApp message suggests holding your breath for 10 seconds and drinking water every 15 minutes will fight the coronavirus.
explanation: There is no scientific evidence of this.

label: false
title: A herbal tea can cure symptoms of coronavirus, even if it is a bioterrorism weapon.
explanation: This claim is false. A "doctor" in nanotechnology and an antivaccine Venezuelan activist said coronavirus can be cured by electromagnetism and/or herbal tea. He also claimed he cured President Chávez from cancer but then died because he didn't follow his treatment.

label: false
title: China did not apologize to Muslims in a song.
explanation: This is a fake translation.

label: false
title: A Shaheen Bagh protest in India was claimed to have coronavirus.
explanation: Hospitals in Delhi confirmed that no Shaheen Bagh protest had tested positive for COVID-19.

label: false
title: 38 % of Americans won’t buy Corona beer due to the coronavirus.
explanation: There is nowhere in the study that several media refer to 38 percent of Americans not buying Corona beer. Instead, it says 38 percent of 737 beer-drinking Americans will in no case buy Corona beer, but that doesn't mean it can be generalized to the overall population. There is also no indication that the lack of desire for the Mexican beer is due to coronavirus, as other media also writes. There can be many different explanations that 38 percent of the respondents do not want to buy the beer, for example that they do not like it.

label: false
title: WhatsApp message suggests holding your breath for 10 seconds and drinking water every 15 minutes will fight the coronavirus..
explanation: There is no scientific evidence of this.

label: false
title: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
explanation: The viral message was not issued by UNICEF. Some measures suggested in the message contradict the WHO’S view on COVID-19 and have no scientific evidence.

label: misleading
title: Qatar shed Iranian fruits fearing coronavirus.
explanation: Misbar did not find any official country data on the disposal of Iranian fruit on the market.

label: false
title: Two Chinese nationals in Kenya have been killed after allegedly escaping from quarantine at the Nairobi Airport.
explanation: The reports are false.

label: false
title: Every election year has a disease; coronavirus has a contagion factor of 2 and a cure rate of 99.7% for those under 50 it infects.
explanation: Every year in the U.S. is an election year, if taking into account midterm elections as well as presidential elections, and contrary to the claim, not every election year has had a disease outbreak. The transmissibility of the coronavirus, represented by the “basic reproduction number," is still under study. Currently, the basic reproduction numbers reported for the virus causing COVID-19 range between 2 to more than 6.

label: false
title: A patent that is being shared to claim COVID-19 is old.
explanation: The patent is related to SARS, not COVID-19

label: false
title: Novel coronavirus has a 99.7% survival rate.
explanation: The CDC does not confirm this.

label: false
title: The coronavirus test costs $3,200.
explanation: Patients will not incur costs when tested by the CDC.

label: misleading
title: Shanghai government officially recommends Vitamin C for COVID-19.
explanation: Intravenous high-dose Vitamin C has been used to treat patients with COVID-19 in certain Chinese hospitals, but it has not been recommended by the Shanghai government. .
claim_originated_by: Andrew W. Saul, Orthomolecular Medicine News Service

label: false
title: There is an anti-Chinese protest in Italy due to COVID-19.
explanation: The demonstration was for an anti-Fascist event to commemorate the victim of racism, Valerio Verbano. It was filmed on 2/22/20 in Rome.

label: misleading
title: UNICEF recommendations
explanation: The message is misleading and has the potential to cause fear in India.

label: false
title: The coronavirus outbreak is caused by 5G technology.
explanation: There is no link between COVID-19 and 5G technology. The cause of the disease is proven to be a novel coronavirus. 5G technology uses low-energy radio waves, which do not damage DNA or cells unlike ionizing radiation

label: false
title: No work in several regions of Spain due to coronavirus.
explanation: The link takes you to a picture of a monkey.

label: false
title: Donating plasma or blood is free testing for the coronavirus.
explanation: Currently the test for coronavirus is free.

label: false
title: A confidential governmental document proves that the government has decided to postpone local elections in France because of the outbreak.
explanation: This document is fake. The government did not make this decision.

label: misleading
title: Does France underestimate the outbreak?
explanation: On social networks, many users claim that the number of coronavirus cases in France is underestimated, because there are fewer tests in France than elsewhere. This international comparison is not relevant.

label: false
title: 86 clients of a brothel in quarantine after a prostituted tested positive in coronavirus.
explanation: This claim was a satire shared as real news.

label: false
title: The WHO has issued an alert against buying holy colors from China
explanation: The WHO hasn't issued an advisory against buying Holi colors from coronavirus-hit China.

label: misleading
title: In Kuwait, he sneezed during Friday sermon, and the worshipers expelled him.
explanation: The video is old and was circulationing before the appearance of the virus.

label: false
title: The Success of an Egyptian serum in treating coronavirus.
explanation: The Egyptian Ministry of Health denies that China has officially announced the success of the Egyptian serum to cure COVID-19.

label: false
title: This video shows panic buying in the United States, during the coronavirus outbreak
explanation: The video has circulated online since November 2019, weeks before the novel coronavirus was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

label: false
title: Precautionary measures suggested by UNICEF.
explanation: The viral message was not issued by UNICEF. Some of the measures have no scientific evidence.

location: North Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina
label: false
title: The vaccine against the new coronavirus was created before the disease appeared; three people who recently arrived from China in Sarajevo Canton are under medical supervision and have brought COVID-19 to Sarajevo.
explanation: The British National Health System and the WHO report there is no vaccine yet for COVID-19. As of 3/5/20, there was no confirmation of a coronavirus positive finding in the three patients, and for several days thereafter results were found to be negative.

label: false
title: 80 clients of a brothel were put on quarantine due to coronavirus.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: UNICEF releases coronavirus prevention guidelines.
explanation: UNICEF has not released an advisory; many of the claims are contrary to health experts' advice.

label: misleading
title: Four cases of coronavirus were reported in the West Bank.
explanation: Four cases of COVID-19 were recorded among tourists in Beit Jala in the West Bank. Ma'an News Agency modified the facts with other news entitled "Coronavirus In Bethlehem and the Ministry of Health is Calling For Calm and Waiting For Instructions."

label: false
title: Article says that the Vatican confirmed that the Pope and two assistants have coronavirus.
explanation: There’s no official statement from the Vatican saying that Pope Francis is infected with COVID-19. Pope has felt ill, but not with the coronavirus.

label: false
title: Viral claims propagating UNICEF message about coronavirus.
explanation: Mr. Jeremy Sprigge, communication specialist for UNICEF Sri Lanka, confirmed that “these messages are not UNICEF statements and henceforth FALSE."

label: false
title: NHK World’s Chinese language service calls COVID-19 the “Novel Japanese Coronavirus”.
explanation: What was said on NHK World in Chinese was “a summary of the novel coronavirus infection situation in Japan”, this was mistranslated by some in Japan as "Novel Japanese coronavirus".

label: misleading
title: Photos show a well-stocked vegan shelf while other items are cleared out.
explanation: Circulated online since September 2017, the photo shows panic buying after Hurricane Harvey in the U.S.

label: false
title: Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi Mohammed bin Zayed is infected with coronavirus.
explanation: There is no official news about bin Zayed's infection with the virus.

label: false
title: A post says that there is a movie that predicted the pandemic and it’s called “Coronavirus”.
explanation: The image is false, is manipulated and it uses the cover of the movie “The flu” with the wrong title. There’s no movie called “Coronavirus”.

label: false
title: President Donald Trump tweeted, “Coronavirus vaccine from Israel! Stock market up! Economy even stronger now! Besides US, Israel best at inventions
explanation: President Donald Trump did not tweet this.

label: false
title: The Simpsons predicted the coronavirus pandemic years ago.
explanation: Other than the "Osaka Flu" infecting many residents of Springfield, the events of the 1993 episode "Marge in Chains" have no similarities with the COVID-19 pandemic.

label: false
title: Israel creates a vaccine for the coronavirus.

label: false
title: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
explanation: Please click the link to read the full article

label: false
title: Masks from Wet Wipes effectively prevent coronavirus transmission
explanation: Wet tissue material makes dust, dirt and bacteria stick more easily.

label: misleading
title: The common cold is the only type of coronavirus.
explanation: Coronaviruses can cause different illnesses in animals and humans, including the common cold. However, they can also lead to severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).

label: false
title: This is a photo of the first Moroccan infected with the virus.
explanation: The photo is from an advertisement for an opthamologist clinic in Algeria.

label: false
title: Dr. Lupita Yamamoto has found a vaccine that destroys the coronavirus.

explanation: The number of deaths in official reports as of 3/3/20 were lower than stated in this article.

title: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.

title: The first dog was infected with coronavirus.
explanation: A dog in Hong Kong was tested weakly positive for coronavirus but didn't show any symptoms so far.

label: false
title: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi
explanation: According to Narendra Modi's official social media account and Indian media, Modi did not make such a statement.

label: false
title: COVID-19 was created in 2014 by an English institute.
explanation: A viral video denounces that the Pirbright Institute of the United Kingdom, created the virus that causes COVID-19. The institute denied the rumors, noting that the virus strain they work with to make a vaccine is different from the new coronavirus.

label: false
title: New coronavirus was registered in 2018.
explanation: It was another type of coronavirus that doesn't affect humans.

label: false
title: Videograph shows COVID-19 is more dangerous than former outbreaks.
explanation: The video is cut at the beginning and the end. The whole video shows COVID-19 is not as dangerous as the former outbreaks or other causes of death.

label: half true
title: “With regard to the cost, let me be very clear
explanation: Pence’s claim over simplifies what is involved in making this coverage assurance because a large swath of private health insurance falls beyond these categories. His statement fails to acknowledge the need for action at the state level and from the private sector.

label: false
title: Gaza Strip Is coronavirus-free.
explanation: 17 cases of COVID-19 in the Gaza Strip as of 3/4/20.

label: false
title: The Obama administration “didn’t do anything about” swine flu.
explanation: The Obama administration responded with two emergency declarations, triggering billions in spending and other public health responses.

label: false
title: A fabricated circular for the Lebanese Ministry of Education regarding the end of the school year.
explanation: The Lebanese Ministry of Education and Higher Education has announced the end of the school year for all different levels of education, after the outbreak of COVID-19 and the appearance of several cases. The circular is false.

label: misleading
title: Cow dung and cow urine can cure coronavirus.
explanation: Dr Sumit Ray, a Senior Consultant, Critical Care Medicine, said that there are no scientific studies to support these claims.

label: false
title: “Man visited Albany, N.Y., days before dying from coronavirus.”
explanation: The image was manipulated to look like it is from ABC News. There is no evidence one of those individuals who died from COVID-19 had recently been to Albany, N.Y.

label: pants on fire!
title: The media “pulled down an entire shelf of goods so that they can present the news of people buying stuff in a hysteria over the coronavirus.”
explanation: An image claims to show a news reporter staging a shot of empty grocery store shelves. The photo is a hoax from Romania.

label: false
title: “The Obama administration made a decision on testing that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing” on the coronavirus.
explanation: The “decision” Trump talks about had its roots in a 2004 law, when George W. Bush was president. The FDA’s policy pre-dated the Obama administration.

label: false
title: Garlic, onions and other traditional medicine recipes are treatments against the new coronavirus.
explanation: There is no evidence that garlic or traditional medicine can protect from the new coronavirus, according to the WHO.
claim_originated_by: Secretary of the National Security and Defense Council Oleksiy Danilov

label: misleading
title: Prince of Qatar is infected with coronavirus.
explanation: The Emir of Qatar has been bedridden for several days, and his temperature is high, indicating that he has COVID-19. But the claim is false.

label: false
title: Consuming large doses of Vitamin C can stop the spread of coronavirus.
explanation: There is no evidence that consuming large doses of Vitamin C cannot stop the spread of coronavirus.

label: false
title: “The State of Florida has announced measures that all workplaces with 10 employees or more are to have paid mandatory leave to avoid the spread of COVID-19 coronavirus starting on March 6, 2020. All schools are to close for 2 weeks also from March 6.”
explanation: As of 3/5/20, Florida is not shutting down schools and businesses for two weeks.

label: false
title: European Health Organization (EHO) announced that eating beef can cure coronavirus.
explanation: There is no official institution with the name European Health Organization (EHO). Also, no authority in the European Union has announced that eating beef will cure coronavirus.

label: false
title: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon can prevent COVID-19.
explanation: Vitamin C and warm water with lemon have no known effect on the novel coronavirus.

label: false
title: First policeman infected with coronavirus in Ecuador.
